Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Laser-Matter Interactions on Atomic and Nanoscales
Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports the renewal of the REU site at Kansas State University which will have research opportunities for undergraduates focusing on interactions of laser light with matter at atomic and nanoscales. The participants will engage in significant research projects and related experiences during the summer. At the core of the program are the research projects with mentors from the faculty. Participants will do research on how atoms and molecules behave in intense and ultra-fast optical and xray pulses, how scattered laser light reveals the structure of nanoparticle crystallization and gel formation, and how light interacts non-linearly in optical fibers; they will develop computer codes for calculations of atomic interactions in Bose-Einstein condensates and codes for modeling nanoparticle self-assembly from lattices to gels. This experience will be supplemented by a small series of lectures that provide the background these students need to carry out their projects. The participants will gain experience in explaining their research work to a variety of audiences and will also engage in reading on and discussion of ethical behavior in science. Social activities, both organized and spontaneous, will enrich this undergraduate research experience. This award is supported by the Physics Division and the Division of Social and Economic Sciences.

Twelve students from around the United
States have been funded by the National Science Foundation to do research in
physics at Kansas State University each summer from 2009-2011. Most of these
students were from smaller colleges that offer fewer opportunities for research
than we have available at KSU. For most of them this research experience
confirmed their choice of a career in physics or engineering but also helped a
few of them decide to pursue interests in medicine, law, or a non-technical area.
It is good for our country for bright students to make an informed career
choice early in their education, and this NSF program, Research Experiences for
Undergraduates (REU), has advanced that national interest.



They have sometimes done independent research,
mentored by a KSU professor, but usually joined existing research groups that
are already involved in basic research. The research they did ranged from
computer simulations of how crystals evaporate to experimental work on how
lasers can be used to manipulate the way molecules break up into their
constituent atoms. Here are a few examples of the projects and the outcomes.



One student joined the KSU
neutrino-physics group. These physicists are working on an experiment in France
in which neutrinos are detected by the light produced when they interact with a
special liquid in a large container. Inside the liquid are light sensors and
other devices. A clear resin is a component of some of these devices, and it
was not known how much light would be produced by interactions in the
resin.  An REU student at KSU in 2010
studied this and her results -- that the resin would produce no light -- were
reported to the group of experimenters working in France.  When unexpected light was later found in the
operation of the detector, it stimulated other research groups to check her
results, and her work was found to be correct. She is now in graduate school
studying nuclear physics.



When a laser beam hits a molecule the
molecule may break up, but there are many ways that the break-up can occur. One
REU student joined a group at KSU that studies this process and made great
progress during the ten-week program. She continued the work during her senior
year at a small mid-western college, occasionally returning to KSU to do
further experiments. She won the Apker award for the best undergraduate physics
research in the nation in 2011 and is attending graduate school on a
prestigious Department of Energy Fellowship. Her publications already include
five peer-reviewed papers on related work.
